item.title: Suitable hardware for Artificial life? Benchmarking matrix multiplication
item.description: Parallelism is one of the trickiest issues I am facing in experiments using evolutionary algorithms to optimize neural networks (for Artificial Life, RL tasks…etc). If I avoid tackling it, everything will run super slow, thus reducing massively the room for experimentation.

item.title: When to Leave - kupajo
item.description: We obsess over arrivals. Hellos and handshakes. Wonka limping toward the crowd, then somersaulting into song. But we rarely talk about exits. And yet knowing when to leave might be more important than knowing when to show up.

item.title: The Roganification of the Male Mystique
item.description:
Joe Rogan changed.
Not all at once. Not in some catastrophic fall from grace. But gradually — the way signals turn to noise when the frequency gets stuck.
And now, millions of men are trying to survive a collapsing world by bulking up their biceps and shrinking their imaginations.
I saw

item.title: LLMs Expand Computer Programs by Adding Judgment
item.description: Traditional computer programs rely on rigid logic, yet the real world is full of ambiguity. The arrival of Large Language Models (LLMs) means that computer programs can now make “good enough” decisions, like humans can, by introducing a powerful new capability: judgment. Having judgment means that programs are no longer limited by what can be specified down to the level of numbers and logic. Judgment is what AI couldn’t make robust before LLMs. Practitioners could program in particular logical rules or build machine learning models to make particular judgments (such as credit worthiness), but these structures were never broad enough or dynamic enough for widespread and general use. These limitations meant that AI and machine learning were used in pieces, but most programming was still done in the traditional way, requiring an extreme precision that demanded an unnatural mode of thinking. LLMs are changing this entirely.
